Bioinformatics Training + Tule Elk

Coordinating bioinformatics workshops in person and virtually

Before I started graduated school, I worked as a Bioinformatics Training Coordinator the the Lab for Data Intensive Biology. During this year I coordinated:

  • 30+ half day workshops
  • 10+ two day workshops
  • 10+ weeks of intensive workshops

Most workshops were beginner to intermediate levels with some specialized advanced sessions as well.

Topics included:

  • Bioinformatics Workflow Skills: genomics, transcriptomics, metagenomics analyses
  • Computational Skills: Python, R, data visualization
  • Cloud Compute Tools: Amazon Web Services, Jupyter Notebooks

I frequently acted as a helper during these workshops to assist with questions or software installation problems.

I also organized a series of online workshops. Although these are now common, they werenâ€™t as popular back in 2016!

A screencap of streamed workshops.
Streaming workshops required multiple computers and dongles.

During this year, I also participated in instructing and helping Software Carpenty bioinformatics workshops.

I wanted to apply my newfound bioinformatics skills, so I worked with a group to generate the first Tule Elk genome, which was used to track Tule Elk populations based on single nucleotide variations.

A tweet from the F1000 Research announcing the Tule Elk genome accouncement. I am forever in awe of the beautiful graphic design work.

The Tule Elk draft genome announcement can be viewed at https://doi.org/10.12688/f1000research.12636.2.

The github repository is at https://github.com/jessicalumian/tule-elk
